critique: This document outlines the regulations for the Selective Service Act of 1940, detailing the process of drafting men into military service. It focuses on quotas, credits, and procedures for delivering registrants to induction stations. Given the context of World War II, the document reflects a strong emphasis on national security and a centralized approach to mobilizing manpower. There is no discussion of immigration, diversity, or economic regulation. The document expands executive power by implementing the draft.
